Crucial space is created by predicting building-level damages before they occur, allowing state actors and non-governmental organizations to distribute resources effectively and minimize or prevent losses. We introduce PREDISM, an ensemble model that combines ResNets and fully connected layers over decision trees to capture image-level and meta-level information, accurately estimating the vulnerability of man-made structures to disaster occurrences. Our model performs well and is responsive to tuning across various disaster types, highlighting the potential for preemptive hazard damage modeling.

1 Introduction

1.1 Natural Hazard Threats and Climate Risk

Natural hazards have posed a threat to humanity worldwide for years, and this threat is expected to worsen as the climate changes (Tippett, 2018). Specifically, sea-level rise could amplify flooding threats, leaving low-elevated coastal regions at risk of permanent flooding (Marsooli et al., 2019; Miura et al., 2021b). Warm and dry conditions can cause severe and widespread wildfires, which could become more frequent as global warming extends fire seasons in the future (Halofsky et al., 2020). More extreme rainfalls are expected due to a warming climate (Knutson et al., 2015), and the slowing of tropical cyclones, also caused by global warming (Kossin, 2018). These threats are among the many outcomes of climate change. Regions with little or no hazard occurrences in the past may be devastated by amplified hazards (Miura et al., 2021a). Such natural hazards affect millions of people and cost billions of dollars (He and Cha, 2018; Kreibich et al., 2019). Given limited resources, it is critical to predict and prepare effectively for future hazards to mitigate their threats (Miura et al., 2021c). Understanding the nature of threats (i.e., magnitude, frequency) can allow for proper preparedness and a quicker recovery. For example, stakeholders and communities can implement protective measures (e.g., barriers) or strategies (e.g., evacuation plans, insurance) against future hazards.

1.2 Hazard Damage Studies with Machine Learning

The machine learning community has been interested in the disaster damage domain in the context of climate change. For example, Crisis-DIAS from Agarwal et al. (2020) uses multi-modal platforms to consolidate post-disaster damage levels across information sources, while Zhang et al. (2020) discusses human-in-loop entities to accurately estimate post-disaster damages. Chen et al. (2020) explored convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and hyperparameters to merge pre-disaster and post-disaster images for the same. Unlike most previous studies, which use machine learning for building damage and climate change (Agarwal et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2020; Chen et al., 2020), focusing on after-the-fact damage estimation of a natural hazard occurrence, we introduce PREDISM, which models the susceptibility of buildings, landscapes, and habitats to future calamities. Forecasting future risks allows residents and governments to prepare with an appropriate contingency fund, facilities, and preparedness. PREDISM does not depend on disaster occurrence; instead, it predicts damages that could happen from a future hazard with a given intensity. This is beneficial to affected communities if the future hazard risk, given the climate risk, can be identified without massive past data but with current community information (e.g., present satellite imagery over the area). For instance, identifying building damage levels prior to a hazard of an arbitrary magnitude hitting the area would provide insight to stakeholders and communities.

Our models are fine-tuned on disaster-type open-source building datasets (Gupta et al., 2019), along with adjoining fully connected layers activated with meta-information to generate building-level hazard-level risks of future damage.

2 Methodology

2.1 Data Schema

We use the xBD dataset from Gupta et al. (2019) as the basis for fine-tuning our ensemble model. The xBD data spans 15 countries and 45,361 square kilometers, covering 850,736 individual buildings' data. The 30 GB of data is manually appended with additional meta-information (see Appendix). We also gather information for xBD building images that include damage levels incurred on past occurrences to train our model ensemble predictor. Each damage level is classified into one of "unclassified," "no damage," "minor damage," "major damage," or "destroyed." During inference using PREDISM, when sufficient information is available, the model can predict building-level hazard risks.
